Award.AwardTitle: Catalytic Studies of the Production of Biodegradable Polymeric Materials from Carbon Dioxide and Renewable Resources
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Catalysis Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation supports Professor Donald Darensbourg of Texas A & M University, for the development of new catalysts for the copolymerization of carbon dioxide and oxiranes/oxetanes. The goals of this research are to use mechanistic and kinetic measurements to optimize catalyst structure, and to assess the potential of the resulting copolymers as biodegradable materials. This important class of catalyst and the copolymers themselves are important in terms of renewable chemical resources and for their proposed use as biodegradable materials.

Broader impacts of the research include the Darensbourg group developing catalytic reactions that can take one of the by-products of fossil fuel combustion, CO2, and use it in reactions to produce new materials. By using only catalytic amounts of compound in these reactions, an "atom economical approach" will be realized. Furthermore, the resulting compounds are likely to be biodegradable, with potential applications in medicine and physiology. The PI's laboratory has developed a national reputation for integrating research with undergraduate education through an REU program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Because petroleum is a non-renewable resource, alternative sources of chemical carbon will be required as the world-wide supplies of petrochemicals decline during the current century. The use of carbon dioxide as a carbon replacement for the synthesis of useful organic chemicals can serve to contribute to a sustainable chemical industry.  Currently, the major  industrial chemical conversions of CO2 into viable economic products are limited. A promising future technology for CO2 utilization is the alternating copolymerization of CO2 and epoxides to provide biodegradable polycarbonates. Because CO2 is such a thermodynamically stable molecule, a major challenge in its use is the discovery of effective catalysts to facilitate its transformations. In addition, there can be numerous health and safety benefits associated with utilizing CO2 as a reactant and/or solvent in chemical processes. Our studies funded by this NSF grant have defined the mechanistic details which enables the development of processes  for the coupling of a wide variety of epoxides derived from either petroleum or renewable resources with carbon dioxide.  These findings offer a complementary technology to carbon sequestration and storage.

Our results are reported upon in detail in over forty publications appearing in peer-reviewed journals. The findings represent the work of numerous graduate/undergraduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and visiting scientists. All of these coworkers have gone on to contribute to the US and worldwide scientific workforce in either academic or industrial positions.

Some of the key discoveries from our research program are captured in the attached graphics.


Last Modified: 08/07/2015
Modified by: Donald J Darensbourg

    Macromolecules, 2014, 47 (21), pp 7347?7353
